metadata.title: Fetal Alcohol Syndrome  Occupational Therapy
synonyms: fetal alcohol spectrum disorder  occupational therapy
anatomical location body part affected: Brain, CNS, face, cardiovascular system, and extremities(29)
description: Fetal alcohol spectrum disorder (FASD) is an umbrella term that refers to a range of neuropsychological and behavioral deficits that result from prenatal exposure to alcohol(31)

Fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS) falls under the umbrella of fetal alcohol spectrum disorders (FASDs)(1) –Individuals affected by alcohol may have some but not all of the FAS characteristics. Individuals who are less affected may be included in the spectrum with diagnoses such as fetal alcohol effects, prenatal alcohol effects, alcohol-related birth defects, and alcohol-related  neurodevelopmental disorder (ARND)
Believed to be the leading known cause of developmental disabilities in the United States(30)
Most preventable cause of developmental disabilities(25)

The most common defects are low birth weight with failure to catch up in size and weight, intellectual disability, facial and cardiac abnormalities, delayed postnatal growth, delayed development, and limb deformities(29)

Alcohol consumption interferes with the metabolism of vitamins. Many vitamins are key to typical embryonic development, and with poor vitamin absorption and impaired metabolism there is a greater risk for atypical development of the embryo(27)
FAS tends to be underreported. Authors of a cohort study found that 70% of Australian mothers of babies with FAS lacked an alcohol-related  diagnosis during their pregnancies(28)

Terminology related to FASD is evolving as researchers learn more about the wide range of effects that result from prenatal alcohol exposure(30) –FAS –Partial FAS –The term alcohol-related  neurodevelopmental disorders (ARND) may be declining in use(31) –Alcohol-related  birth defects (ARBD) –Neurobehavioral disorder associated with prenatal alcohol exposure (ND-PAE) remains incompletely defined but may become the accepted diagnostic term for moderate PAE(31)  –Static encephalopathy associated with PAE is a suggested diagnostic term for severe PAE effects(31)

Diagnostic criteria, according to the U.S. CDC:(1) –Facial dysmorphia: smooth philtrum, thin vermillion border, small palpebral fissures –Growth problems –CNS problems -Structural deformities (small head circumference) -Functional problems: global cognitive deficit (low IQ) or deficits in three or more of the following domains: cognition executive function, motor function, attention and hyperactivity, social skills, other (such as sensory processing, language, or memory problems) –Confirmation of maternal alcohol consumption during pregnancy

According to updated criteria from the Institute of Medicine, in order for a diagnosis of FAS to be made the child must have the following:(34) –At least two or more key facial features such as shortened palpebral fissures, thin vermillion border, or smooth philtrum (vertical groove between nose and upper lip) –Prenatal and/or postnatal growth retardation (10th percentile or less) –Deficient brain growth, head circumference (10th percentile or less) –Neurobehavioral impairment or cognitive deficit in at least 1 neurobehavioral domain > 1.5 SD below the mean (executive functioning, specific learning impairment, memory or visual-spatial  impairment) –Documented prenatal alcohol exposure

According to University of Washington (UW) Fetal Alcohol Spectrum Disorder 4-digit  diagnostic code, in order for a diagnosis of FAS to be made the child must have the following:(2) –Growth abnormalities –Facial appearance abnormalities –CNS structure and function abnormalities –History of alcohol exposure
Mean age at diagnosis of FAS is 4 years, but it can be diagnosed at any age(3)

ICD-10 codes.P04.3: fetus and newborn affected by maternal use of alcohol
ICD-10 codes.Q86.0: fetal alcohol syndrome (dysmorphic) (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Heart defects, such as ventricular septal defect or atrial septal defect(4)
Behavioral regulation problems, including:(6,31) –Mild to moderate irritability(6) –Poor habituation(6) –Sleep problems(6,31) –Feeding difficulties(6)

Cognitive development –Delayed cognitive development, including impaired memory, learning, attention, and problem solving(4) –Deficits in executive function (planning, organization, inhibition)(6,31) –Intellectual disability(6) – some individuals with FAS have intellectual disability; others are in the low average to average range on standardized intelligence tests

Children who have prenatal alcohol exposure (PAE) and postnatal traumatic stress (e.g., physical abuse, neglect, sexual abuse) have lower intelligence scores than those with postnatal traumatic experience alone. Children with prenatal  alcohol exposure and postnatal trauma experience more deficits in language, attention, memory, and cognition and sleep disturbances and exhibit more behavioral problems than children with PAE in the absence of other trauma (37,40) –Based on a study in the United States in which authors investigated the prevalence and impactof trauma or adverse childhood experiences (ACEs) on the neurodevelopment of children with FASD –The higher the ACE score, the greater the risk for neurodevelopmental disorders such as ADHD, comprehension deficits, sleep disorders, and cognitive impairments –A cross-sectional  review of patients’ charts from a regional developmental center identifiedchildren with FASD and non-FASD  controls. Authors recorded the number of ACEs and neurodevelopmental disorders in each patient’s chart –203 subjects were included in the review (98 with FASD and 105 non-FASD  controls) –Group mean age was 8.6 years and 64.5% were male –Researchers found that children with FASD were more likely to have any ACEs (mean 5.3) and their ACEs scores were 3.7 points higher than non-FASD  controls (mean 1.69) (40)

Children with FASD have difficulty with social engagement with peers. Research indicates that participation in evidence-based interventions such as Children’s Friendship Training (CFT) improves social skills, self-concept,  and caregiver-reported  social skills (38)

Children and adolescents with FASDs have poor skills in the areas of social interaction, communication, and executive functioning (EF)(8) –Based on a study in the United States with 83 preschool-aged children (ages 2.5 to 5.0) with PAE and 95 adolescents (49 with PAE and 46 controls aged 8–16) –Each child completed EF tasks and parents completed social functioning (SF) and communication inventories about their child’s abilities –Results showed the greatest deficits in SF and EF in the adolescent groups with PAE and to a lesser extent, impairments in the early childhood group with PAE –Findings suggest that deficits in EF and SF increase throughout development.Theyhighlight the importance of including EF training as a component of social skills interventions starting in early childhood. Authors state that further research is needed
contraindications precautions to test: Children are at risk for unintentional injuries due to impulsivity, lack of behavioral inhibition, and poor judgment(31)

causes: Alcohol consumption by mother during pregnancy–Pregnant women should be told to abstain from alcohol, as there has been no safe level of alcohol intake established forpregnancy(26)–According to the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP), no amount of alcohol consumption is safe during any trimesterof pregnancy(31)-First-trimester  drinking produces 12 times the likelihood of giving birth to a child with FASD-Drinking alcohol during the first and second trimester increases the likelihood of giving birth to a child with FASD 61times-Drinking in all trimesters increases the likelihood of giving birth to a child with FASD by 65 times
pathogenesis: Alcohol is a teratogen that interferes with nerve cell development and function(1)

Several mechanisms potentially are responsible for the range of FASD characteristics. These mechanisms likely act atdifferent stages of development and/or with different doses of alcohol. They include the following:(6)–Alterations in the regulation of gene expression–Interference with mitogenic and growth factor responses involved in neural stem cell proliferation, migration, anddifferentiation–Disturbances in molecules that mediate cell–cell  interactions–Alcohol-induced  endocrine dysfunction and activation of neuroinflammation, which impact brain development and havelong-term  effects on immune and endocrine response–Activation of molecular signaling controlling cell survival or death (e.g., growth factors deprivation, oxidative stress,apoptotic signaling, suppression of NMDA, glutamate, and GABA receptors)–Derangements in glial proliferation, differentiation, and function
risk factors: Risk factors for alcohol use during pregnancy(12)–Physical abuse and violence–Smoking tobacco-Pregnant women should also eliminate their exposure to smokeless tobacco products and electronic cigarettes(26)–Poor physical health–Psychiatric distress (including depression)–Previous inpatient treatment for mental health problems and/or illicit drug use–Prior dysfunctional alcohol use (binge drinking, abuse, and dependence)
Maternal blood-alcohol  concentration, has the greatest impact on alcohol-related  deficits. Higher blood-alcoholconcentrations are associated with greater alcohol-related  deficits(11)
Prenatal alcohol exposure in the first trimester(11)
Genetics – women with sensitivity to alcohol may be more at risk for damage to the fetus(11)

The level of prenatal alcohol consumption in pregnant women increases in the following situations:(11)–High maternal age–Low maternal education level–Maternal drug use–Child custody changes within a family–Paternal drug use–Low socioeconomic status

overall contraindications precautions: Children with FASDs are at risk for unintentional injuries due to impulsivity, lack of behavioral inhibition, and poor judgment(31)
If there is suspicion of an unsafe or abusive home situation, clinician should notify the physician and youth and family services
There may be an increased risk for suicide attempts in adults with FASD;(31)if patient describes suicidal thoughts or ideations, immediately refer to physician or emergency services
Obtain consent of parent/guardian before evaluating and treating a minor
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

contraindications precautions to examina: Children are at risk for unintentional injuries due to impulsivity, lack of behavioral inhibition, and poor judgment(31)

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Ask parent/caregiver about child’s prenatal history, any complications with labor/delivery, and prematurity. Ask about child’s achievement of developmental milestones -More than 50% of children born with FAS are born preterm(33) -Authors of a study of 2-year-olds  in Germany who were born preterm and in whom FAS was diagnosed determined that reduced length of exposure to alcohol in utero resulted in significantly higher scores for mental development than in children with FAS born at term(33)

course of treatment.medical management: Document treatments received. Document any surgical interventions. Document therapeutic interventions received at school or another facility
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed; are they being taken? Are they effective? Because children with FASDs sometimes also meet diagnostic criteria for ADHD, ask about stimulant medications being taken for hyperactivity, impulsivity, and inattentiveness(11,13) Methylphenidate(13) Dextroamphetamine(13) Modafinil(13) Atomoxetine(13)
diagnostic tests completed: Blood alcohol level of mother during pregnancy(4)
CT scan or MRI of brain(4)
Routine assessments used for diagnosis of FASDsinclude:(6)
Neurobehavioral assessments (behavioral, motor, visual-motor,  cognitive, developmental, neuropsychometric, adaptive behavior, social skills, communication, education/academic, neurological)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help. Ask about use of choline, a nutritional supplement, as it may help improve learning, memory, and cell function(14) Canadian guidelines for diagnosis of FASD suggest that nutritional interventions may mitigate the effects of exposure to alcohol(34) Evidence suggests that antioxidant therapy may be an effective approach to mitigate the effects of prenatal exposure to alcohol(35)
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpfulAsk what factors (e.g., environments or conditions) aggravate or improve symptoms and/

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: or behaviors, and length of time each item is performed before the symptoms and/or behaviors are experienced or are easedUse body chart to document location and nature of symptoms, if applicable, although pain is not characteristic of FASD. Use nonverbal scales as appropriate, such as the Oucher scale and Face, Legs, Activity, Cry, Consolability scale (FLACC)Document nature of symptoms (e.g., constant vs intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling), if applicable. Is there a time of day or length of time after a medication is taken that the patient is more cooperative?Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to other external variablesDocument number of wakings/night. Persons with FASDs often have disruptions in sleep cycle.(6)In a study of 27 children with FASD in Canada, researchers found that sleep problems were often undiagnosed due to the focus on daytime behavior presentations, such as inattention, hyperactivity, and cognitive/emotional impairments(23)Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/ or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician. Document any alcohol or illicit drug use in older children, as persons with prenatal exposure to alcohol are at risk for drug and alcohol abuse later in life(31)Document any use of supplemental oxygen or complaints of breathing difficulty -Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _________________________ -Some children with FASDs have learning impairments and have difficulty at school behaviorally and academically(5) -Document academic difficulties, if any -Document teacher’s impressions of child’s behavior at school

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Ask parents/caregiver about any past medical history of developmental disorders
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patients/caregiver about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders. Mental health problems are prominent in persons with prenatal alcohol exposure.(15)Depression, anxiety, aggression, and inattention are common.(6,15) Children with FASDs sometimes also meet diagnostic criteria for ADHD(11)
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient and/or family about other symptoms he or she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Document child’s participation in extracurricular activities, recreational or competitive sports, and school
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Document any adaptive equipment used by patient and the amount of assistance patient requires for self-care  tasks. Indicate if specific limitations are experienced in the school setting
social and occupational history.living environment: Document who lives with the patient, the number of stairs in home, number of floors in home, any personal care assistance, and any bathroom modifications. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home, community, or school and if any modifications are needed. Ask about caregiver support/stress(5)

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assess need for assistive/adaptive equipment for self-care  or school tasks
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess static and dynamic balance reactions as appropriate for age –Clinical observations of postural control(19)
cardiorespiratory function and endurance: Bimanual Coordination Test(11)  test of speed and accuracy of bilateral coordination. With increased task complexity, children with FASDs generally perform more poorly than controls
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Manual muscle strength testing for all extremities without tone or coordination issues. Note any asymmetry or abnormality Neuromotor development –Pediatric Early Elementary Examination (PEEX 2)(7)–standardized assessment for children aged 6–8 years; assesses attention, memory, neuromotor function, visual-spatial  processing, temporal-sequential  function, higher-level  cognition –Pediatric Examination of Educational Readiness at Middle Childhood (PEERAMID 2)(7)– standardized assessment for children aged 9–14  years; assesses attention, memory, neuromotor function, visual-spatial  processing, temporal-sequential function, higher-level  cognition –Peabody Developmental Motor Scales, Second Edition (PDMS-2)  –standardized assessment for children from birth to age 5 years; assesses gross and fine motor skills and visual motor integration Perception  (e.g., visual field, spatial relations) –Beery-Buktenica  Developmental Test of Visual-Motor Integration(19)subtests include visual perception test, motor coordination test, Goodenough Harris drawing test  –NEPSY (a developmental NEuroPSYchological assessment)(41)– subsections include visual attention, visual spatial function, language, sensorimotor function, learning, and memory
relevant tests and measures.posture: Observe patient’s sitting and standing posture. Note any postural instability during movement/activity
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess both active and passive ROM in all extremities. Note any asymmetry or abnormality Self-care/activities  of daily living  (objective testing) –Scales of Independent Behavior–Revised  (SIB-R)(8) –standardized assessment of performance of daily activities
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Sensory testing –Infant/Toddler Sensory Profile(39) –Sensory Profile Caregiver Questionnaire(39) –Short Sensory Profile (SSP)(9)– parent-reported  sensory behaviors; total and section scores are classified as definite difference, probable difference, and typical performance
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –Social skills -Social Skills Rating System – Parent Version(20) –Behaviorclinical, borderline, and normal -Personality Inventory for Children(11) –assessment of behavioral deficits -Adaptive Behavior Assessment System, 2nd edition (ABAS-II)(10)
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Arousal, attention, cognition (including memory, problem solving) –Kaufman Brief Intelligence Test (K-BIT)(7)–normed assessment that measures verbal and nonverbal intelligence of persons aged 4–90  years –Conners Rating Scales (CRS-R)(7)– normed assessment that measures psychopathology and problem behavior in children and adolescents –Test of Non-verbal  Intelligence, 2nd edition (TONI-2)(8) – standardized assessment of cognitive ability, using abstract and figural problem-solving –Continuous Performance Task (CPT)(16) –objective assessment that measures sustained attention over time. Task consists of presenting visual or auditory stimuli over defined period of time at a predetermined rate. Patients are asked to respond to stimulus – incorrect responses are omission errors (missing target stimuli) and commission errors (delayed or incorrect responses) –Bayley Mental Scale in Infancy(41)– prenatal alcohol exposure is associated with lower performance on this assessment –WISC – 4th edition (WISC-IV)(10) –WISC Preschool and Primary Scale of Intelligence – 3rd edition (WPPSI-III)(10) –Differential Ability Scales(41)– standardized assessment of cognitive function for individuals aged 2–17 years

other: Patients with FASDs are at increased risk for falls. Follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies
Children with FASDs are at risk for unintentional injuries due to impulsivity, lack of behavioral inhibition, and poor judgment(31)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Referral to occupational therapy for difficulties with adaptive behaviors, ADL performance, and motor skills at home (e.g., for self-care)  and/or at school (e.g., writing), leading to lack of independence at home and in the community and poor academic performance
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out Williams syndrome(34) Down syndrome(34) Brachmann–de  Lange syndrome(34) Fragile X syndrome(34) Aarskog syndrome(1) Noonan syndrome(1) Dubowitz syndrome(1) Toluene embryopathy(1) Fetal hydantoin syndrome (fetal Dilantin syndrome)(1) Maternal PKU fetal effects(1)
prognosis: There is no cure for FAS(31)
Persons with FAS can lead productive lives(31)

Factors that increase risk for negative outcomes (e.g., delinquency, school failure, alcohol and drug abuse) are:(6,31)  –IQ ≥ 70 -Researchers suggest the reason for this is that persons with higher IQ qualify for and receive fewer services –Diagnosis of an alcohol-related  disorder

Persons with history of prenatal alcohol exposure are at significantly increased risk for mental health problems, psychiatric confinement, school failure, delinquency, incarceration, sexually inappropriate behaviors, and substance abuse problems later in life(31)
The impact of neurobehavioral deficits from alcohol exposure on a person’s ability to function and adapt in his or her environment may be improved or worsened by postnatal experiences(5)
Past or current parental abuse, poor attachment, and poor quality of childhood caregiving environment are significantly associated with poor life outcomes(5)
Early diagnosis of FAS is associated with decreased risk of poor outcomes(21)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Physical therapy Social work Psychology Speech therapy Youth and family services Drug and alcohol counseling V ocational rehabilitation
other considerations: Treatment of individuals with FASDs must include providing education to parents and caregivers on the nature of the individual’s disability, including the ways deficits will manifest in his or her daily life, appropriate goals, and how to advocate for services. There is a tendency for behavior problems to be misunderstood as poor motivation, lack of empathy, or defiance as opposed to a function of neurocognitive impairments. Parents and caregivers should then help to educate medical, mental health, and education professionals who may be working with the patient but lack training with this population(5)
treatment summary: There is limited research-based  evidence on the efficacy of interventions for children with FASDs(42) –Based on a 2015 systematic review of the literature –Thirty-two  studies were identified: studies included those on interventions targeted at neurocognitive functioning, self-regulatory  deficits, attention control, specific areas of dysfunction (math skills, fire/street safety skills, social skills, memory rehearsal), motor skills, and impact of structured parenting programs on child behavior –Three of the studies produced promising evidence on improving self-regulatory  behaviors in childhood, nine studies offered evidence of improvements in specific areas of dysfunction, and four studies showed initial promising evidence that parents/caregivers benefit from support with child behavior. Interventions for improving social skills showed consistently strong results –Of all the studies included, only 19 were rated as “strong” in study design and none received a “strong” rating for selection bias or blinding –Studies with randomization (RCT) are lacking. Authors concluded that further research is needed targeting the early childhood population

Children with FAS who participated in a friendship training group for social skills learning reported improvement in communicating with peers and handling disappointment and frustration(20) –Based on a description by Dutch authors of a social skills intervention group for children with FASDs –Eleven children, aged 7–12  years, participated in seven 90-minute  sessions –Sessions were structured with activities that all children could do or that could be modified that allowed development and practice of specific social skills and were fun and engaging –Children were also given homework to do during the week, such as inviting a friend to play a game, calling a friend, or complimenting a friend during the week –Pre and post program questionnaires were filled out by parents; the Social Skills Rating System–Parent  Version was used –Seven of eight questionnaires that were returned indicated improvements in addressing communication and handling disappointment and frustration

Caregiver training has been shown to positively impact educational outcomes in children with FAS(5)  –Training to understand effects of FAS on development and learning –Sensory integration training/education to caregivers to reframe behaviors and make sensory-based  accommodations in home and routine to improve function –Guidance on understanding their child’s cognitive and learning profile –Support on communication with their child regarding deficits at an appropriate developmental level

A step-by-step  program that mentors parents with FASDs is effective at achieving goals(21) –Based on retrospective analysis in Canada of 24 parents: 50% in whom a FASD was diagnosed, 25% with possible prenatal alcohol exposure, 25% with suspected prenatal alcohol exposure but no formal assessment available during the study –Intervention consisted of one-on-one  mentorship program over 3 years; mentors helped in accessing supports such as housing, addiction treatment, financial support, parent supports –Goals of program were to reduce risk of family breakdown, strengthen parenting skills, increase independence and success within families –Four goal categories showed an increase pre and post intervention: self-care  and health, self-reliance,  community connection, and parenting

Math interactive learning experience (MILE) program(17) has been shown to be effective in improving learning readiness and mathematics comprehension -A short-term  socio-cognitive  program designed to improve behavior and learning that includes caregiver education regarding FASD, support for learning readiness, and mathematics training -Twenty-eight  Canadian children aged 4–10  years with confirmed FASD or PAE diagnosis were randomly assigned to either the MILE intervention or contrast group -Following a brief one-on-one  individualized intervention, children in the MILE group demonstrated significantly greater changes in math achievement compared to the contrast group -Children of older age, lower IQ, and confirmed PAE without FASD diagnosis demonstrated the most significant math achievement changes in the MILE group -Educating caregivers about FAS and special education and building positive behavioral regulation skills reduced problem behaviors -Providing tutoring services is an appropriate way to address limitations in academic functioning in children with FAS –Cognitive training (CT) including both parent and child education to improve executive functioning and self-regulation  in children with FASD -Cognitive training (CT) may include direct skills training, teaching of strategies to reduce maladaptive behaviors, specific training programs (attention training, self-regulation,  anger management etc) and how to adapt/accommodate the environment for success -Preliminary results from a study on the effects of transcranial current stimulation (tDCS) and augmented cognitive training (CT) in children with FASD indicate that the intervention is well tolerated and that combining tDCS and CT improves functional outcomes as measured by attention scores -Preliminary results from a study on neurocognitive habituation indicate that children with FASD can improve executive functioning and self-regulation through training. The training program included both child and parent education

Researchers who conducted an RCT in the United States found neurocognitive habilitation to be a promising intervention for improving executive functioning and emotional problem solving in children with FAS or alcohol-related neurodevelopmental disorder(24) –Forty children were in the treatment program; there were 38 controls –Outcome measures were the Behavior Rating Inventory of Executive Function (BRIEF) and the Roberts Apperception Test for Children (RATC) –Intervention included components of the Alert Program (a curriculum that helps children improve self-regulatory skills by teaching them how to identify their arousal level and then how to alter it based on situational demands) and treatment strategies used with the pediatric traumatic brain injury population, such as occupational therapy, family psychoeducation, and interventions to improve memory skills, emotional awareness, and cause and effect reasoning –Significant differences between the treatment and control groups were demonstrated

Researchers in the United States compared the motor control skills, specifically goal-directed  force responses, of 19 children with heavy prenatal alcohol exposure with those of 25 typically developing children(36) –Children with heavy prenatal alcohol exposure experienced deficits in goal-directed  force responses  –Impaired motor control skills impact everyday functional movement and can lead to negative social and psychological

desired outcomes: Maximize function and participation across daily living, social, and schooldomains(8)
Improve adaptive behavior involving social, personal living, and community living skills(8)

Wechsler Preschool and Primary Scale of Intelligence – 3rd edition (WPPSI-III)(10)

Beery-Buktenica  Developmental Test of Visual-Motor Integration(19)
Social Skills Rating System – Parent Version(20)
Peabody Developmental Motor Scales, Second Edition (PDMS-2)(18)
Behavior Rating Inventory of Executive Function (BRIEF)(24)

maintenance or prevention: Alcohol abuse or dependence screening tools(22) Alcohol Use Disorders Identification Test (AUDIT) – 10-item  screening tool that asks about quantity, frequency, and 5 or more drinks on one occasion, personal/social consequences, dependence symptoms CAGE – 4-item  screen asking about need to Cut down, Annoyed by criticisms about drinking, Guilty about drinking, need for Eye-opener  in the morning T-ACE  – alcohol screen for pregnant women, asking about Tolerance, being Annoyed by criticisms about drinking, need to Cut down, and need for Eye-opener  in the morning TWEAK – screen that asks about Tolerance, Worry by family members over drinking, need for Eye-opener  in the morning, Amnesia, and need to Kut down
TWEAK and AUDIT screens are more accurate in identifying problems in women than the CAGE screen(22)
The U.S. CDC recommends that all women of childbearing age be screened for alcohol use and educated about the consequences of alcohol consumption in pregnancy(43)

Persons with history of prenatal alcohol exposure are at risk for substance abuse problems later in life; therefore, it is important to provide education about alcohol use and risks of drinking during pregnancy (1,2)
